questions.stem: According to DSM-5, which factor is most critical for distinguishing a paraphilia from a paraphilic disorder?
options: The intensity of the sexual interest
The presence of distress or impairment, or action on non-consenting persons
The duration of the sexual interest
Whether the interest involves illegal behavior
questions.explanation: DSM-5 distinguishes paraphilia (atypical sexual interest) from paraphilic disorder, which requires: (1) personal distress (not merely from societal disapproval) OR (2) functional impairment OR (3) acting on the interest with non-consenting persons. A paraphilia alone is not a mental disorder; only when it causes distress/impairment or involves non-consent does it become a disorder.

questions.stem: A man is referred after arrest for exposing his genitals to women in public parks. He reports recurrent urges and fantasies about exposing himself for over a decade, deriving sexual excitement from victims' shock. He feels distressed about these urges but acts on them repeatedly. Which paraphilic disorder is present?
questions.explanation: Exhibitionistic disorder involves recurrent, intense sexual arousal from exposing genitals to unsuspecting persons, manifested by fantasies, urges, or behaviors over ≥6 months, causing distress or impairment, or acting on these urges with non-consenting persons. His distress and non-consensual behavior clearly meet disorder criteria. Voyeurism involves observing, frotteurism involves touching.

questions.stem: Which paraphilic disorders specifically require action on non-consenting persons for diagnosis (i.e., fantasy/urges alone without distress are insufficient)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: For voyeuristic, exhibitionistic, frotteuristic, and pedophilic disorders, Criterion B requires acting on urges with non-consenting persons OR clinically significant distress/impairment. These inherently involve non-consent. Sexual masochism is self-directed (consensual by definition when alone) so only requires personal distress/impairment—acting on a masochistic fantasy alone doesn't involve non-consent.

questions.stem: Match each paraphilic disorder with its target/focus of sexual arousal.
columns: Nonliving objects or specific body parts

correctAnswers.Fetishistic disorder: Nonliving objects or specific body parts

questions.explanation: Each paraphilic disorder has specific focus: Voyeurism = observing unsuspecting persons disrobing/in sexual activity. Frotteurism = touching/rubbing against non-consenting person. Fetishism = nonliving objects or nongenital body parts. Transvestism = cross-dressing with sexual arousal. All require ≥6 months duration plus distress or non-consent action.

questions.stem: A man reports exclusive sexual attraction to prepubescent children for over a decade. He has never acted on these attractions and is extremely distressed by them. Under DSM-5, he meets criteria for [[1]] because [[2]]. Treatment would emphasize [[3]].

2: He has acted on urges with minors
He has intense fantasies/urges with clinically significant distress
He has exclusive attraction to children

correctAnswers.2: He has intense fantasies/urges with clinically significant distress

questions.explanation: Despite not acting on urges, his clinically significant distress elevates this from pedophilia (paraphilia) to pedophilic disorder. DSM-5 requires intense attraction to prepubescent children plus either distress/impairment OR acting on urges. Treatment focuses on CBT-based relapse prevention, managing urges, and building protective factors. Antiandrogens may be adjunctive.

questions.stem: Categorize each paraphilic disorder according to whether it primarily involves non-consenting persons/victims or whether it can occur without victims.
questions.explanation: Voyeurism, exhibitionism, and frotteurism inherently involve non-consenting persons (observing, exposing to, or touching unsuspecting individuals). Sexual masochism (self-directed), fetishism (objects), and transvestism (cross-dressing) can occur privately without victims. This distinction affects legal implications and treatment focus—those involving non-consent have forensic considerations.
